metadata.value: Page 1a of 3. A letter written by Albert of Brandenburg, (also known as Albrecht von Brandenburg and Albert of Mainz). In 1513, he became archbishop of Magdeburg. In 1514, he also became the elector and archbishop of Mainz. In 1518, he was created cardinal. Albert was famously called out by Martin Luther for his financial practices. This letter is written in German. It extends over 2 pages. Page 1 has been digitised twice – once showing a small foldout clipping on the page, and once showing the foldout opened. The foldout is a small piece of paper with both printed and handwritten text. The typed text reads “Albert II., cardinal de Brandenburg. 1490-1545” and it has been pasted on to the letter near the upper left edge of the page. The letter sheet for this letter has been archived and digitised. The remains of a red seal are still visible. The letter is archived as part of a larger collection described in the Laing handlist as “Autographs of foreign Statesmen, etc.” which includes papers from several other cardinals.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph letter, p.1, with fold out opened

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2. This letter is written in Dutch by Fernando Alvarez de Toledo y Pimentel, also known as the Grand Duke of Alba. The letter bears the Duke's signature, as well as at least one other signature. Also archived with this letter is the letter sheet, which still shows the mark of where the seal would have been, although nothing of the seal remains. There are non-contemporary pencil notes written on the letter sheet. Fernando had long and brutal military and diplomatic careers, serving under King Charles I of Spain and Phillip II of Spain. In 1531, he became the Third Duke of Alba; in 1541 he was named High Steward to the King of Spain; he became governor of Milan from 1555-1556; he became viceroy of Naples from 1556-1558; from 1567-1573, he established the Council of Troubles (or Court of Blood) in the Netherlands to punish brutally anyone associated with Protestantism and the 1566 Beeldenstorm (Iconoclasm) in the Netherlands; from 1580-1582 he became Viceroy of Portugal and from 1581-1582, became Constable of Portugal.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: The witty and entertaining exploits of George Buchanan
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: The Witty and Entertaining Exploits of George Buchanan, who was Commonly called the King's Fool The Whole Sis [sic] Parts Complete. To Which is Added Witty and Entertaining Jests, &c.
metadata.label: Variant Title

metadata.value: Title page from a popular Scottish chapbook, which was reprinted many times throughout the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. This edition was printed and sold in Niddery's Wynd (Edinburgh). The title page contains a spelling error: six is printed as "sis". The sixth edition contains "Added Witty and Entertaining Jests, &c" not included in earlier editions. The page displays a woodcut image of a man. Above the printer's information at the bottom of the page, "[Edinburgh]" as the place of publication has been written in ink by hand. The currently undigitised artefact that this page comes from is an interesting volume. Interleaved with the 1781 pages are manuscript pages and illustrations from c. 1822. Numbers referencing annotations and notes have been written into the original pages, including numbers for notes which the new editor never completed. This hybrid edition/manuscript contains a handwritten page that states: “’One Hundred Years hence’ to be published, by the then Secretary of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, - a new and improved edition, of The Witty Exploits of George Buchanan; with suitable illustrations from the most famous pews of this critical and imaginative Age; and adorned with elegant engravings from original drawings by distinguished Artists. The mentioned illustrations are by Alexander Corse and Alexander Christie and are distributed throughout the volume. No full name is given of the new editor, but the secretary of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland from 1819-1822 was John Dillon, so it is possible that he is the editor. David Laing was also a long-standing member of this Society, possibly indicating where he came to acquire this book.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: 1 of 2. A holograph letter in Latin written by Isaac Casaubon. Casaubon, a classical scholar and ecclesiastical historian, was born in Geneva in 1559. He worked in France and England, gaining a great reputation in Europe and publishing several famous works. He was highly skilled in Latin and Greek. He died in London in 1614. The letter sheet for this letter, which includes fragments of a red seal, are also archived and digitised.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Gabriel, comte de Montgomery, seigneur de Lorges was captain of the Scots Guards of King Henry II of France. In 1559, however, during a jousting match, wood from Montgomery's lance mortally wounded Henry II. At the time of this letter (1562), Montgomery was living in Normandy and had converted to Protestantism. This letter is written in French.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: 1 of 2. A letter from Giovanna d'Aragon (1502-1575), who was a patron of the arts, printers and religious reform in Naples during the Renaissance. She was the widow of Italian poet and noblewoman Vittoria Colonna's brother Ascanio Colonna. This letter is written in Italian. The upper right corner of the paper has been worn and/or torn away. Both recto and verso sides of the page have been digitised.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: 1 of 3. A letter written in a numbered code, which includes the decoded message written above the numbers. The letter is written by the comte de Montmorin de Saint Herem, Armand Marc (1745-1792). Marc served under Louis XVI, beginning as a gentleman-in-waiting to the king whilst he was dauphin, and eventually becoming ambassador to Madrid in 1777, recalled to become governor of Brittany, and serving the ministry of foreign affairs in 1787. He was friend and ally to Mirabeau and strove to find a compromise between royalists and revolutionaries. This friendship and position eventually led to his death in the September Massacres. The letter is written in French and is from Marc's ministry years. In the bottom left corner of the first and third page, the name O'Kelly appears, indicating that this might be the addressee and decoder of the letter.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: A note from Charles-Francois Delacroix, who was a statesman involved in the French Revolution and who was appointed as the French Minister of Foriegn Affairs from 3 November 1795 - 15 July 1797 under the Directory. The note was written while he was serving in this capacity. The note is written in French and the date is given as "Paris, le 14 pluviose. An 4e de la Republique francaise" in the French Republican (or Revolutionary) Calendar. In the Gregorian Calendar, this date refers to 3 February 1796.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This book is one of three plan books from the Edinburgh Musical Society archived in the Laing collection. This image shows two pages, one from December 1781 and one from January 1782. The pages list the names of various classical pieces of music handwritten in ink.

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2. A handwritten letter in German written by Gesenius, dated 24 October 1822. The recto and verso of the page have been digitised. The verso side has the date and Halle as the place of creation written down. There is some bleed-through of the ink on both sides of the paper. Gesenius was a student at the Universities of Helmstedt and Gottingen studying philosphy and theolgy. He became a highly successful professor at the University of Halle, especially in his teachings on Hebrew and Old Testament exegesis. He died in 1842.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2. A letter written in Dutch and dated 6 June 1649 by Hendrik Hondius. Hondius was a Dutch draftsman, engraver, printer, publisher and mathematician. He is perhaps best known for the engravings that he published, and particularly those that appeared in Pictorum aliquot celebrium praecipue Germaniae inferioris Effigies (1610). Although the left edge of the page is jagged and has been torn, the paper is well preserved and the ink remains clearly legible. The verso of this page has also been digitised.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Page 2 of 2. A letter written in Dutch and dated 6 June 1649 by Hendrik Hondius. Hondius was a Dutch draftsman, engraver, printer, publisher and mathematician. He is perhaps best known for the engravings that he published, and particularly those that appeared in Pictorum aliquot celebrium praecipue Germaniae inferioris Effigies (1610). Although the right edge of the page is jagged and has been torn in places, the paper is well preserved and the ink remains clearly legible. The recto of this page has also been digitised.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2. A French letter written by Jean-François Joly de Fleury, a French politician and state counciler. He was one of the ministers who worked under the "triumvirate" established by Louis XV in 1760, led by Jules Flammermont (Chancellor Maupeou), the Abbé Terray , and the Duke d’Aguillon. This body was intended to replace the Parlements in France. This particular letter is dated 13 March 1770 and bears Joly de Fleury's signature. It is held in the Laing collection under La.II.654, a collection described in the handlist as a "large collection of miscellaneous papers, autographs, etc., some Italian, the rest chiefly French; both preceding, during, and after the Revolution".
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2. A letter written in Latin by Athanasuis Kircher and dated 17 September 1678. As described by the Athanasius Kircher at Stanford project: "During his lifetime, the Jesuit polymath Athanasius Kircher (1602-1680) was widely regarded as the physical embodiment of all the learning of his age. He had over 760 correspondents, including scientists, Jesuit missionaries and world potentates. The subjects discussed in his voluminous correspondence cover the entire range of his interests. Letters sent to Kircher were commonly accompanied by curious natural objects or artefacts for Kircher’s expanding collection in Rome and reports of astronomical observations or experiments performed by the global network of Jesuit missionaries. In return, Kircher sent his powerful patrons medicines and balsams produced in the pharmacy of the Jesuit college in Rome, and elaborate machines of his devising such as the Mathematical Organ, and example of which is now preserved in the Museo Galileo in Florence."
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: 5 of 28. Loose vellum pages that were once bound. These pages include the poem "The Perilous Adventures of the Famous Hero and Knight Thewerdanck" ("Les Avantures perilleuses du fameux Heros & Chevalier Tewrdannecks"). The original poem is attributed to Melchoir Pfintzing (Pfinzing), Provost of Saint Sebald’s in Nuremburg, and is written in German (referred to for this poem in some bibliographies as the Teutonic language). The poem includes a Dedicatory Epistle addressed to Charles V in 1517 from Nuremburg, as well as 118 wooden plate engravings. The version of the poem collected here is a manuscript copy of the 1517 poem in its original language written out by Jacques Leclabart over the years 1771-72. Leclabart published the poem in the 1784 book _Hist. des Avantures, faits et actions courageuses due heros et Chevalier Thewerdanck_, which also includes a printed summary and history of the poem by Leclabart, both of which are written in French. As reported by the book’s introductory matter, Jacques Leclabart was a member of l'Academie Royale d'Ecriture de Paris.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph quarantine note for Peter Kinnaird and his coachman., f.41r

metadata.value: Holograph quarantine note for Peter Kinnaird and his coachman.
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: A signed and once-sealed handwritten note freeing Peter Kinnaird and his coachman from quarantine. The letter is written in Italian and is dated 25 February 1710. The note is signed by Cornaro Licor. At a much later date, two notes have been penciled onto the paper. One reads "Kinnaird (Peter) and coachman" and the other reads "Certificate freeing from Quarantine".
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Letter of Carl Linnaeus to Dr. John Walker, f.7.r

metadata.value: Letter of Carl Linnaeus to Dr. John Walker
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: 1 of 3. A copy of an original letter written in Latin from Swedish botanist, physician, and zoologist Carl Linnaeus to Scottish minister and natural historian Reverend Dr. John Walker. The original letter is dated 20 June 1763, although this date may differ for the copy. Walker was professor of Natural History at the University of Edinburgh from 1779-1803 and he also co-founded the Royal Society of Edinburgh. Linnaeus is best known for formalising binomial nomenclature, and is referred to as the "father of modern taxonomy".
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: 1 of 4. A French memorandum written in the names of Louis XVI and French military commander and politician Charles Francois Dumouriez. This memorandum is dated 28 April 1792, just over a month after Dumouriez had been appointed Foreign Minister, succeeding M. Delessert who was empeached and killed at Versailles. Dumouriez would hold this post for approximately three months, before the government fell again in June, and Dumouriez moved on to other positions in the revolution. The memorandum is signed by Dumouriez and bears a signature reading "Louis" for Louis XVI and the flourish below the signture indicates that it may have been signed by the secretary. The paper is in good condition and the remains of a seal are visible on the fourth page.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: A Yiddish pre-nuptual agreement signed by Emanuel Mendes da Costa. Costa was a naturalist, a librarian and fellow of the Royal Society of London. He was imprisoned for debt in 1754 and was imprisoned again in 1767 for acts of dishonesty while appointed to a clerkship of the Royal Society. He was first married in March 1750 to Leah del Prado, who died in 1763, and he was again married c.1766 to Elizabeth Skillman. He and Skillman had one daughter.
metadata.label: Description
